title: GI0
text: vignette introduces GI0 package functions. \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution modified version Fisher-Snedekor distribution useful describing positive data extreme variation (Frery et al, 1997). probability density function \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution : \(\frac{L^L\Gamma(L-\alpha)}{\gamma^\alpha\Gamma(-\alpha)\Gamma(L)}\frac{z^{\alpha-1}}{(\gamma+zL)^{L-\alpha}}\) \(-\alpha, \gamma, z>0\) \(L\ge1\). GI0 package includes four functions: dGI0 gives density \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution pGI0 gives cumulative distribution function \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution qGI0 gives quantile function \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution rGI0 pseudo-random number generator sampling \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution Section 1 vignette, provide examples applying density, distribution quantile functions. Section 2, draw random samples \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) review sampled distribution histogram. finally, Section 3, analyse \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution using Cullen Frey plot.

title: GI0
text: section look examples applying probability density function, cumulative distribution function, quantile function.

title: GI0
text: calculate density using different values parameters \(\alpha\), \(\gamma\) \(L\), plot values linear semilogarithmic scales.
code: # Create the sequence of input values x <- seq(0.001, 10, length=100) # Apply the dGI) function and plot the output in a line graph plot(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), type = "l", lwd = 2,      xlab = expression(italic(z)), ylab = "Density",      main="GI0 Densities") lines(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), col="red",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=5, p_Looks=1), col="blue",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=3), col="green",lty=1, lwd = 2)  l1<- expression(paste(alpha, "=-1 ", gamma, "=1 L=1")) l2<- expression(paste(alpha, "=-2 ", gamma, "=1 L=1")) l3<- expression(paste(alpha, "=-1 ", gamma, "=5 L=1")) l4<- expression(paste(alpha, "=-1 ", gamma, "=1 L=3"))  legend(x = "topright",                  legend = c(l1, l2, l3, l4),          lty = c(1,1,1,1),                  col = c("black", "red","blue","green"),                lwd = 2) # Semi log scale plot(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), type = "l", lwd = 2,       xlab = expression(italic(z)), ylab = "log(Density)",       main="GI0 Densities", log="y") lines(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), col="red",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=5, p_Looks=1), col="blue",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, dGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=3), col="green",lty=1, lwd = 2)  legend(x = "topright",                  legend = c(l1, l2, l3, l4),          lty = c(1,1,1,1),                  col = c("black", "red","blue","green"),                lwd = 2)

title: GI0
text: calculate cumulative distribution function using different values parameters \(\alpha\), \(\gamma\) \(L\), plot values linear semilogarithmic scales.
code: plot(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), type = "l", lwd = 2,       xlab = expression(italic(z)), ylab = "Probability",       main="Cumulative Distribution Function for GI0") lines(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), col="red",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=5, p_Looks=1), col="blue",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x,pGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=3), col="green",lty=1, lwd = 2)  legend(x = "bottomright",                  legend = c(l1, l2, l3, l4),          lty = c(1,1,1,1),                  col = c("black", "red","blue","green"),                lwd = 2) #Semi-log scale plot(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), type = "l", lwd = 2,       xlab = expression(italic(z)), ylab = "log(Probability)",       main="Cumulative Distribution Function for GI0", log="y") lines(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=1), col="red",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=5, p_Looks=1), col="blue",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(x, pGI0(x, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=1, p_Looks=3), col="green",lty=1, lwd = 2)  legend(x = "bottomright",                  legend = c(l1, l2, l3, l4),          lty = c(1,1,1,1),                  col = c("black", "red","blue","green"),                lwd = 2)

title: GI0
text: calculate quantile function using different values parameters \(\alpha\) \(L\), plot values linear semilogarithmic scales. Note: parameter \(\gamma\) used function.
code: p <- seq(0,1,length=50) plot(p,qGI0(p, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=2, p_Looks=2), type = "l", lwd = 2,       xlab = expression(italic(p)), ylab = "Quantile",       main="Quantile Function for GI0") lines(p, qGI0(p, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=2, p_Looks=2), col="red",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(p,qGI0(p, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=2, p_Looks=3), col="green",lty=1, lwd = 2)  legend(x = "topleft",                  legend = c(l1, l2, l4),          lty = c(1,1,1),                  col = c("black", "red","green"),                lwd = 2) # Semi-log scale plot(p,qGI0(p, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=2, p_Looks=2), type = "l", lwd = 2,       xlab = expression(italic(p)), ylab = "log(Quantile)",       main="Quantile Function for GI0", log="y") lines(p, qGI0(p, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=2, p_Looks=2), col="red",lty=1, lwd = 2) lines(p,qGI0(p, p_alpha=-1, p_gamma=2, p_Looks=3), col="green",lty=1, lwd = 2)  legend(x = "topleft",                  legend = c(l1, l2, l4),          lty = c(1,1,1),                  col = c("black", "red","green"),                lwd = 2)

title: GI0
text: section, sample \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution using rGI0 function plot histogram examine sampled values. function uses ratio two independently sampled gamma variables produce random \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) variable. just one method sampling \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\), however, efficient methods exist (Chan et al, 2018).

title: GI0
text: note distribution right skewed due outliers upper tail, indicative high variation distribution. next plot, truncate x axis view core distribution closer detail.
code: # Sample from the GI0 distirbution set.seed(111) z<- rGI0(1000, p_alpha=-2, p_gamma=4, p_Looks=3) df <- data.frame(z)  # Plot a histogram of the random draws, overlay the kernel density # Use Freedman-Diaconis equation  to calculate the number of bins  hist(df$z, breaks = "Freedman-Diaconis", prob=TRUE,       xlab=expression(italic(z)), ylab="Density",      main="Distribution of 1000 random draws from GI0 distribution")  lines(density(df$z), col = "blue", lwd=2) hist(df$z, breaks = "Freedman-Diaconis", prob=TRUE,       xlab=expression(italic(z)), ylab="Density",       main="Distribution of 1000 random draws from GI0 distribution",      xlim = c(0, 20))  lines(density(df$z), col = "blue", lwd=2)

title: GI0
text: section, examine bootstrapped sample values \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution Cullen Frey plot, plots skewness kurtosis sample alongside common distributions (Cullen Frey, 1999). use fitdistrplus pacakge generate plot (Delignette-Muller Dutang, 2015). parameters used generate sample : \(\alpha = -3\) \(\gamma = 2\) \(L = 3\) can see \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\) distribution adhere theoretical distributions pictured. partially overlaps beta gamma distributions, single distribution appears suitable match \(\mathcal{G}_I^0\).

title: The GI0 Distribution
text: Created part DATA501, Semester 2, 2023. package contains functions ð’¢I0 distribution. functions : dGI0 gives density ð’¢I0 distribution pGI0 gives cumulative distribution function ð’¢I0 distribution qGI0 gives quantile function ð’¢I0 distribution rGI0 pseudo-random number generator sampling ð’¢I0 distribution functions modified check valid parameters passed called. Documentation function created using roxygen2. vignette created outline use function includes references distribution related.
